ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: Read the entirety of the Ion in Greek with selections from other tragedies/comedies in English and secondary scholarship. Since we spent the entire semester on the Ion, I feel like I know the play very well and that I am well-versed in the important scholarship on the work. This class taught me the tragic conventions/how to read tragedy, identify trimeter, improved my Greek, and improved my skills at reading/critiquing/understanding scholarship.

Introduction to tragedy as a genre, knowledge of Euripides' place in this genre, intense engagement with the Ion (both to it as its own text and to the body of scholarship surrounding it), deeper engagement with Classics scholarship and literary criticism, a better handle on the complexities of the Greek poetic language and meter
The course sharpened my Greek and taught me how to read tragedy.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments:
Strengths: Professor Kraus' love for Euripides and the Ion is infectious; even though I began a skeptic of the play, by the end, I think it's one of Euripides' greatest. The course had a great pace, with just the right amount of reading (both primary and secondary per week). Interesting assignments (critiquing commentaries, staging a modern Ion, etc.). Very in-depth, but also felt like we learned a lot about tragedy generally and the historical context. 
Weaknesses: some of the discussions in class would meander and I would've appreciated more close reading/textual analysis at times; we would read about 200-300 lines per week for discussion, but some weeks we had less to discuss than others purely based on the sections we read that week (I'm not sure how to change this though). Also, it would've been nice to read Aristotle's Poetics together, since it was mentioned quite often. Otherwise, wonderful class!

Strengths:
 - The comprehensive approach to the text. I can say I know the Ion more confidently than I can say I know any other text.
 - The comprehensive approach to tragedy as a genre. This was my first class on Greek poetry, and I have a much better handle on the formal and thematic elements of Greek tragedy than before.
 - The emphasis on contemporary theoretical scholarship. I'm especially partial to structuralism and post-structuralism, and it was great to engage with articles that applied these concepts to a work that I became very familiar with.
- The diversity of scholarly and non-scholarly sources. Some of the articles engaged with the Ion in pretty conventional modes of formalist literary theory/criticism. Others were more historically concerned, emphasizing the political moment that the Ion embodies. Still others took the form of reviews of contemporary adaptations of the Ion, and general discourses on the concept of adaptation from the perspective of theater-makers.
- Genuinely interesting assignments. I thought it was a great idea to throw in a paper about how we would adapt a Greek chorus for a modern theater  it was both fun and instructive.
 - Professor Kraus. She's just a wonderful professor. She was exceptional at guiding the seminar, keeping things on-topic while still allowing for free-flowing discussion, and constantly pushing students to engage more deeply by (briefly, but actively) adding her own input to comments.

Weaknesses:
 - None that I can think of. A warning, though: the jump from L3/L4 to L5 is pretty massive.
The course readings could have been a little more integrated, but all around the course was excellent.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: This course was incredible and I recommend it to anyone interested in Greek tragedy.

Absolutely! I'm not sure if Professor Kraus will teach another Greek class in the future, but, whether Latin or CLCV, her classes are amazing. She organizes the syllabus so thoughtfully, and every scholarly article contributed to my understanding of the play. Her grasp of tragedy and Greek is incredible. Euripides was already my favorite tragedian going into this class, and, having read an entire play in Greek, my love and appreciation for his work is even deeper than before. Please take this class!
AbsolutelyI've learned more from this class than any other class I've taken at Yale (although buckle up for an intense workload!)
Yes its excellent, great to sharpen your Greek and learn good material.
